Question: What should I plant in warm weather?
Solution: Plant maize, sunflower, or beans. These thrive in Lesotho's warm seasons (October-March).

Question: What should I plant in cool weather?
Solution: Plant wheat, peas, or cabbage. Ideal for Lesotho's cooler months (April-September).

Question: What are drought-resistant crops?
Solution: Try sorghum, millet, or cowpeas. These need minimal water and survive dry spells.

Question: What are good cash crops in Lesotho?
Solution: Grow cabbage, carrots, and spinach. These sell well in local markets (e.g., Maseru Market).

Question: When should I plant maize?
Solution: Plant maize at the start of the rainy season (October-November). Use spacing: 20-30 cm between seeds, 75 cm between rows.

Question: When should I plant wheat?
Solution: Plant wheat in early winter (May-June) for best yield. Ensure soil pH is 6.0-7.0.

Question: When should I plant sorghum?
Solution: Plant sorghum at the beginning of the rainy season (November). It tolerates drought well.

Question: What is the best spacing for maize?
Solution: Plant maize seeds 20-30 cm apart with rows 75 cm apart. This optimizes sunlight and airflow.

Question: How to increase maize yield?
Solution: 1. Spacing: 20-30 cm between plants; 2. Fertilizer: Apply NPK 15-15-15 at planting and side-dress with urea 4 weeks later; 3. Pests: Control aphids with neem oil (20 ml/liter); 4. Water: 2-3 times/week (5L/m²).

Question: How to know if crops need water?
Solution: Check soil moisture: Insert your finger 5 cm deep. Water if dry; avoid waterlogging.

Question: How to rotate crops?
Solution: Alternate groups yearly: Year 1: Cereals (maize/wheat); Year 2: Legumes (beans/peas); Year 3: Root crops (carrots). This reduces pests/diseases and improves soil.

Question: Why do some plants have big green leaves but no fruits?
Solution: 1. Reduce nitrogen: Stop high-N fertilizers (e.g., urea); 2. Add phosphorus/potassium: Use bone meal (P) or wood ash (K); 3. Pollination: Attract bees with flowering plants or hand-pollinate; 4. Prune: Remove excess leaves to redirect energy to fruits.

Question: Why do crops curl or wilt?
Solution: 1. Water stress: Underwatering - water deeply 2-3 times/week; Overwatering - let soil dry before next watering; 2. Pests: Spray neem oil for aphids/whiteflies; 3. Disease: Remove infected plants; use copper fungicide for fungal issues.

Question: How can I fix yellow leaves?
Solution: 1. Test soil: pH 6.0-7.0 (adjust with lime/sulfur); Nitrogen - apply urea (200g/m²) or compost if low; 2. Adjust watering: Let top 5 cm of soil dry between waterings; 3. Check pests: Spray neem oil (20 ml/liter) if aphids/whiteflies are present; 4. Improve drainage: Add sand/compost to clay soil; 5. Micronutrients: Apply iron chelate if young leaves are yellow (interveinal chlorosis).

Question: How can I encourage fruiting in leafy plants?
Solution: 1. Reduce nitrogen: Switch to low-N fertilizer (e.g., NPK 5-10-10); 2. Add phosphorus: Use bone meal (100g/m²) at flowering; 3. Sunlight: Ensure 6+ hours of direct sun daily; 4. Pollinators: Plant pollinator-friendly flowers (e.g., marigolds) nearby; 5. Prune: Remove 30% of older leaves to redirect energy.

Question: What is the best time to plant beans?
Solution: Plant beans after the last frost (September-October) when soil temperature is >15°C.

Question: How to improve tomato yield?
Solution: 1. Support: Use stakes/cages to prevent disease; 2. Prune: Remove suckers below first flower cluster; 3. Water: Drip irrigation (2-3 times/week; avoid wetting leaves); 4. Fertilize: NPK 5-10-10 at planting + compost every 3 weeks; 5. Pests: Handpick hornworms; use Bt for caterpillars.

Question: How to grow cabbage?
Solution: 1. Soil: Fertile, well-drained (pH 6.5-7.0). Add compost before planting; 2. Planting: Sow seeds 0.5 cm deep, 30 cm apart. Thin to 45 cm; 3. Water: Keep soil consistently moist (2-3 cm/week); 4. Pests: Use row covers to exclude cabbage worms; spray Bt if needed; 5. Harvest: Cut heads when firm (60-90 days).

Question: What is the ideal soil for potatoes?
Solution: 1. Type: Loose, sandy loam (50% sand, 30% silt, 20% clay); 2. pH: 5.0-6.5 (add sulfur if too alkaline); 3. Prep: Mix in compost (5 kg/m²) before planting; 4. Drainage: Raise beds 30 cm if soil is heavy.

Question: When should I plant carrots?
Solution: Plant in early spring (August-September) or late summer in loose, rock-free soil. Harvest in 70-80 days.

Question: What fertilizer should I use for maize?
Solution: Use NPK 15-15-15 at planting (100g/m²) and side-dress with urea (50g/m²) 4 weeks later.

Question: What fertilizer should I use for wheat?
Solution: Apply urea (46% N) at sowing (50g/m²) and DAP (18-46-0) at tillering (30g/m²).

Question: When should I apply fertilizer?
Solution: 1. At planting: 1/3 of total dose; 2. Early growth: 1/3 dose (3-4 weeks after planting); 3. Before flowering: Final 1/3 dose.

Question: What organic fertilizers are best?
Solution: 1. Compost: 2-5 kg/m² (balanced nutrients); 2. Cow manure: Well-rotted (1-2 kg/m²; high N); 3. Green manure: Plant clover/alfalfa and till in before flowering; 4. Bone meal: For phosphorus (100g/m² at planting).

Question: How to mix organic fertilizer?
Solution: 1. Spread 2-3 cm of compost/manure over soil; 2. Till to 15 cm depth before planting; 3. Avoid fresh manure: It burns plants (compost for 6+ months first).

Question: What is the best fertilizer for fruit trees?
Solution: Use NPK 8-3-9 in early spring (200g/tree) and potassium in autumn (100g/tree).

Question: How do I control aphids on maize?
Solution: 1. Spray neem oil: 20 ml/liter water, weekly; 2. Introduce predators: Ladybugs or lacewings; 3. Remove infested leaves: Burn or compost far from field; 4. Reflective mulch: Confuses aphids.

Question: How do I control cutworms on wheat?
Solution: 1. Bt spray: Bacillus thuringiensis (follow label rates); 2. Handpick: Check plants at dusk; drop worms in soapy water; 3. Barriers: Wrap stems with aluminum foil; 4. Trap crops: Plant early mustard to attract cutworms away.

Question: How do I protect crops from locusts?
Solution: 1. Pheromone traps: Place around field edges; 2. Biological spray: Metarhizium anisopliae fungus; 3. Early planting: Avoid peak locust seasons (check local alerts); 4. Physical barriers: Fine mesh nets for small plots.

Question: How to identify leaf miners?
Solution: 1. Signs: White tunnels inside leaves; tiny black larvae; 2. Confirmation: Hold leaf to light to see larvae; 3. Common crops: Tomatoes, spinach, beans.

Question: How to prevent fungal pests?
Solution: 1. Spacing: 30-50 cm between plants for airflow; 2. Watering: Drip irrigation (avoid wetting leaves); 3. Rotation: Don't replant same family (e.g., tomatoes) in same spot; 4. Resistant varieties: Choose disease-resistant seeds.

Question: How to prevent aphid infestations?
Solution: 1. Companion plants: Marigolds, garlic, or chives; 2. Reflective mulch: Silver plastic confuses aphids; 3. Early scouting: Check leaf undersides weekly; 4. Beneficial insects: Release ladybugs (1000/hectare).

Question: How to control caterpillars?
Solution: 1. Handpick: Remove eggs/larvae daily; 2. Bt spray: Bacillus thuringiensis (organic, safe); 3. Pheromone traps: For moths (e.g., tomato hornworm); 4. Crop rotation: Avoid planting brassicas in same spot.

Question: How do I treat maize leaf blight?
Solution: 1. Remove infected leaves: Burn or compost away from field; 2. Copper fungicide: Spray 20g/10L water weekly; 3. Rotation: Wait 2 years before replanting maize; 4. Resistant varieties: Plant hybrids like 'SC403'.

Question: What causes yellow leaves in crops?
Solution: 1. Nitrogen deficiency: Pale yellow, older leaves; 2. Overwatering: Yellow + wilting; 3. Iron deficiency: Yellow veins (young leaves); 4. Pests: Stippling or sticky residue (aphids).

Question: How can I prevent crop diseases?
Solution: 1. Rotation: 3-year gap between same crop families; 2. Sanitation: Remove plant debris after harvest; 3. Resistant seeds: Use certified disease-free seeds; 4. Soil solarization: Cover wet soil with clear plastic for 4-6 weeks pre-planting.

Question: Why do some fruits rot on the plant?
Solution: 1. Fungal infection: Spray sulfur (20g/10L) or copper fungicide; 2. Prune: Improve airflow by removing inner branches; 3. Calcium: Add gypsum (100g/m²) if blossom-end rot occurs; 4. Harvest promptly: Pick ripe fruit to avoid spread.

Question: Why do some leaves curl?
Solution: 1. Upward curl: Herbicide damage or viral infection (remove plants); 2. Downward curl: Overwatering or aphids (check undersides).

Question: How to control powdery mildew?
Solution: 1. Remove infected leaves immediately; 2. Spray sulfur: 20g/10L water weekly (or baking soda: 5g/L); 3. Improve airflow: Space plants 30-50cm apart; 4. Resistant varieties: Choose mildew-resistant seeds.

Question: How to prevent blights?
Solution: 1. Rotation: 3-year gap for tomatoes/potatoes; 2. Mulch: Use straw to prevent soil splash; 3. Watering: Drip irrigation (never overhead); 4. Copper spray: Apply preventively every 2 weeks.

Question: How can I improve poor soil?
Solution: 1. Add organic matter: 5cm compost + 2cm sand annually; 2. Test pH: Adjust with lime (pH <6) or sulfur (pH >7); 3. Mulch: Straw or grass clippings to retain moisture; 4. Cover crops: Plant clover in off-season to fix nitrogen.

Question: What is the best soil for maize?
Solution: 1. Texture: Loamy (40% sand, 40% silt, 20% clay); 2. pH: 6.0-7.0 (test with kit); 3. Prep: Till in 5kg compost/m² before planting; 4. Drainage: Raise beds if water pools.

Question: How do I test my soil?
Solution: 1. Home kit: Follow instructions for pH/N-P-K; 2. Lab test: Send to Lesotho Agricultural Research (LARI); 3. DIY drainage test: Dig 30cm hole; fill with water. If it drains <1cm/hour, improve drainage.

Question: How to prevent soil erosion?
Solution: 1. Contour plowing: Plow along slope contours; 2. Cover crops: Plant vetch or rye in off-season; 3. Mulch: Straw or wood chips (5cm thick); 4. Windbreaks: Plant trees/shrubs on windward sides.

Question: How to improve sandy soil?
Solution: 1. Compost: Mix in 30% compost by volume; 2. Clay: Add 10% bentonite clay; 3. Mulch: Use straw to retain moisture; 4. Fertilizer: Apply slow-release organic fertilizer (e.g., blood meal).

Question: How to improve clay soil?
Solution: 1. Sand: Mix in 30% coarse sand; 2. Compost: Add 20% compost for structure; 3. Raised beds: Improve drainage; 4. Gypsum: 100g/m² to break up clay.

Question: How often should I water my crops?
Solution: Water 2-3 times/week (5-10L/m²), adjusting for: Rainfall (skip if >20mm rain in past 24 hours); Soil type (sandy: daily; clay: every 4-5 days); Crop stage (more water during flowering/fruiting).

Question: What are efficient irrigation methods?
Solution: 1. Drip irrigation: 30-50% water savings; ideal for rows; 2. Soaker hoses: Good for small gardens; 3. Rainwater harvesting: Collect in barrels for dry spells; 4. Timing: Water early morning (6-9 AM) to reduce evaporation.

Question: How do I prevent waterlogging?
Solution: 1. Raise beds: 30cm high for heavy soils; 2. French drains: Gravel-filled trenches to redirect water; 3. Mulch: Straw or wood chips absorb excess moisture; 4. Crop selection: Grow water-tolerant crops (e.g., rice, taro).

Question: When should I water fruit trees?
Solution: Water deeply 1-2 times/week (20-40L/tree): Young trees: Daily for first month; Mature trees: Increase to 50L during fruit set; Method: Drip irrigation at root zone.

Question: How to conserve water?
Solution: 1. Mulch: 5-10cm of straw reduces evaporation by 30%; 2. Drip systems: 90% efficient vs. 60% for sprinklers; 3. Rain barrels: Collect roof runoff for irrigation; 4. Soil prep: Add compost to hold moisture.

Question: How does climate change affect farming?
Solution: Impacts: Erratic rains, higher temps, new pests, soil degradation. Adaptations: Use drought-tolerant crops (sorghum, millet), plant heat-resistant varieties (e.g., 'Pannar 473' maize), monitor crops weekly, add organic matter annually.

Question: How can farmers adapt to climate change?
Solution: 1. Crop diversity: Grow 3+ crops to spread risk; 2. Water management: Drip irrigation + rainwater storage; 3. Soil health: Cover crops and compost to retain moisture; 4. Early warning: Use SMS alerts for weather/pests (e.g., mAgri).

Question: When is maize ready for harvest?
Solution: Harvest when: Husks are dry and brown; Kernels are hard (20-25% moisture). Method: Twist cob downward; store at 13% moisture.

Question: How should I store harvested maize?
Solution: 1. Dry: Spread in sun for 3-5 days or use a dryer; 2. Clean: Remove debris and damaged kernels; 3. Containers: Use airtight bins with dried neem leaves (natural pest control); 4. Location: Cool, dry place (e.g., raised rack in shed).

Question: How to reduce post-harvest loss?
Solution: 1. Drying: Sun-dry grains to <13% moisture; 2. Storage: Use hermetic bags (e.g., PICS bags) for grains; 3. Pest control: Add dried chili or neem leaves to storage; 4. Handling: Avoid bruising fruits/vegetables.

Question: When is wheat ready for harvest?
Solution: Harvest when: Grains are hard and moisture <14% (usually 4-5 months after planting, May-June in Lesotho). Method: Cut stalks 10cm above ground; thresh after drying.

Question: How to store vegetables?
Solution: Leafy greens: 0-4°C, 90% humidity (e.g., fridge crisper); Root crops: Cool, dark place (e.g., buried in sand); Tomatoes: Room temp (never fridge) until ripe.

Question: What should I feed my cows?
Solution: Feed ratio: 60% grass/hay, 30% maize silage or stover, 10% protein supplement (e.g., soybean meal). Tip: Rotate grazing areas to prevent overgrazing.

Question: How to prevent livestock diseases?
Solution: 1. Vaccinate: Annual shots for common diseases (e.g., anthrax); 2. Quarantine: Isolate new animals for 2 weeks; 3. Sanitation: Clean shelters weekly with lime; 4. Nutrition: Balanced diet to boost immunity.

Question: How do I manage poultry waste?
Solution: 1. Compost: Mix with carbon (straw/sawdust) 1:1; turn weekly; 2. Biogas: Use in digesters for energy (1kg waste → 50L gas); 3. Fertilizer: Dry and apply to crops (1:10 ratio with soil).

Question: What feed is best for goats?
Solution: Feed plan: 60% grass/hay (e.g., napier grass), 30% concentrates (maize, soybean), 10% minerals (salt + phosphorus blocks). Tip: Free-range grazing reduces feed costs.

Question: How to prevent chicken diseases?
Solution: 1. Vaccinate: Newcastle + IBD at 1, 3, and 6 weeks; 2. Coop hygiene: Clean daily; lime wash monthly; 3. Ventilation: Ensure airflow but no drafts; 4. Quarantine: Separate sick birds immediately.

Question: How can I sell my farm produce?
Solution: Selling options: 1. Local markets: Maseru Market (stalls rent for ~M50/day); 2. Cooperatives: Join Lesotho National Farmers’ Union for bulk sales; 3. Direct sales: Supply restaurants/hotels (e.g., Avani Hotel); 4. Online: Use Facebook groups or WhatsApp farmer networks.

Question: How do I calculate farm profit?
Solution: Profit formula: Revenue – (Seeds + Fertilizer + Labor + Transport + Storage) = Profit. Track expenses: Use a notebook or app (e.g., FarmLogs). Example: If you sell M1000 worth of cabbage and spend M400, profit = M600.

Question: What fruits grow well in Maseru?
Solution: Best fruits for Maseru: Apples (plant in winter; needs chilling hours), Pears (similar to apples; less maintenance), Peaches (thrives in warm summers), Strawberries (plant in early spring; use mulch).

Question: When should I plant tomatoes?
Solution: Plant after last frost (September-October): Spacing: 50 cm between plants; Support: Use stakes/cages; Soil: Add compost + calcium (crushed eggshells).

Question: When should I plant strawberries?
Solution: Plant bare-root strawberries in early spring (August) or autumn (March). Spacing: 30 cm apart; Soil: Well-drained, pH 5.5-6.5; Mulch: Straw to retain moisture.

Question: How to prune fruit trees?
Solution: Pruning steps: 1. When: Late winter (dormant season); 2. Tools: Clean, sharp secateurs; 3. Cuts: Remove dead/diseased branches; thin to 10-15 cm between branches; 4. Shape: Open center for sunlight.

Question: How to increase fruit yield?
Solution: Yield boosters: 1. Pollination: Plant pollinator-friendly flowers (e.g., marigolds); 2. Thinning: Remove excess fruit (leave 10-15 cm apart); 3. Fertilizer: NPK 10-10-10 at flowering; 4. Water: Drip irrigation; avoid wetting fruit.

Question: Why do fruits drop prematurely?
Solution: Causes & fixes: 1. Water stress: Mulch and water consistently; 2. Nutrient deficiency: Apply balanced fertilizer; 3. Pests: Use pheromone traps for fruit flies; 4. Temperature: Protect from late frosts with row covers.

Question: How to plant spinach?
Solution: 1. Sow: Seeds 1 cm deep, 10 cm apart; 2. Thin: To 20 cm when 5 cm tall; 3. Soil: Fertile, pH 6.5-7.0; add compost; 4. Harvest: Cut outer leaves in 40-50 days.

Question: When to plant carrots?
Solution: Sow in spring/autumn in loose soil: Plant in early spring (August-September) or late summer; Harvest in 70-80 days (when roots are 2 cm wide).

Question: How to prevent bolting in lettuce?
Solution: Bolting prevention: 1. Shade: Use 30% shade cloth in hot weather; 2. Water: Keep soil consistently moist; 3. Variety: Choose heat-resistant types (e.g., 'Buttercrunch'); 4. Plant time: Sow in cool seasons (spring/autumn).

Question: How to improve vegetable yield?
Solution: Yield tips: 1. Soil test: Adjust pH (6.0-7.0) and nutrients; 2. Water: Drip irrigation + mulch (straw); 3. Spacing: Follow seed packet guidelines; 4. Fertilizer: NPK 10-5-5 every 3 weeks.

Question: Why are some vegetable leaves yellow?
Solution: Fix yellow leaves: 1. Nitrogen: Add blood meal (100g/m²) or compost; 2. Water: Reduce if soggy; increase if dry; 3. Pests: Spray soapy water (10ml/L) for aphids; 4. Disease: Remove infected leaves; rotate crops.
